I tried some crickets and they tasted like crackers. I really didn’t expect that eating something protein rich would taste like that.

Anyway we should eat bugs at least indirectly. We could raise black soldier fly on food waste and use these to feed chickens and we eat the chickens/eggs. They are rich in calcium and protein so we would need less grains to feed the chickens and reduce pollution from waste at the same time while producing fertilizer. Can raise black soldier fly on manure as well so we can make the whole system even more efficient. Those could also be used to other animals like pigs etc. could also be processed and separate the fat from proteins so we can balance the nutrients and make dry food instead of feeding them directly.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>4365658
in the BSF lifecycle it will stop eating a few days before migrating to a drier location to become a pupae, so they empty their digestive tracts by themselves. This behavior is used on automatic harvesting systems. While they are edible and supposedly taste good I know people are put of by the idea of eating bugs so my proposal is to use them for animal feed. They could be used to make feed for any animal that would eat bugs normally like fish, birds and pig and probably should be safe for herbivores as well since they will eat animal protein if given the chance. They could be processed into pet food as well and probably will be better than all the grain they put on regular pet food.

In my experience, it's better to get an adult cat over a kitten. They tend to have set personalities after a certain age. Don't go in looking for a specific breed, just check out cats for their personalities. Cat breeds do differ but not majorly like dogs. Here's how I picked out my incredibly friendly cat:
>Go to shelter
>Cats are all in cages in a big room, maybe 40 cats in there
>Find cats that have an interest in interacting with me, coming up to the end of the cage and meowing or looking very interested
>Open cage doors and see how the cats interact
>Some cats were cautious to sniff, some hissed, one cat was just immediately interested in getting pet
>Take him out of the cage and he is incredibly affectionate and chatty
>See why he hasn't been adopted yet, despite being friendly
>He was missing half his fur from licking it off when he had fleas as a stray so he looked ugly as hell
>He also had tranny surgery from urinary issues so he takes a little extra care (really just feeding him wet food and making sure he isn't stressed out)

His fur grew back and he has a great personality. He loves people and will hang out and get attention from everyone when we have social events as long as there are no dogs around.

With crabs/crayfish there are two problems: they eat plants and they pull plants. You could check and see if there is some plant that they wouldn't eat and is hard to pull or plants that grow so fast that even if they eat it there still is plenty more. threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
How do you deal with a clingy cat who has abandonment issues?

My little kitten was a stray before I took him in, I believe he was around a month old, he could (kinda) walk by himself, but he was still only eating kitten formula. He could engage in light play.
He's now around 5 months, And he's the clingiest dang cat alive. If I'm not in the room with him he meows at the top of his lungs and wants to pull up the carpet. He also zero sense of boundaries, he plays way too rough after repeated "gentle" scoldings. At first I just completely ignored him and disengaged in play, but then he tried to make an ambitious jump on the back of my chair and we had to make an emergency vet visit (he was fine, just needed a shot for swelling)
After that, I tried hissing back at him to let him know he was being too rough, I figured since he didn't grow up with siblings he never learned boundaries and that's how they would do it.
After that didn't work I started being a little rougher, I would (gently) toss him away while trying to do a combination of the previous two, but that didn't work either. Lately he's been getting on my nerves more, and since he's more grown his bites REALLY hurt even if I know he just wants to play. I accidentally scruffed him off of me the other day, and I still feel kinda bad from it.
I'm worried this might be a behavior he retains growing into adulthood, but I've never really owned a male kitten before. I'm not sure if he'll calm down after he gets neutered in a month or not.

Any help is appreciated, thanks.
Pictured is my little super model.

>So four days ago, my mom and I spot a baby raccoon in the wild.

>Secondly, my grandmother/her mother did the same thing with the neighborhood cats when she lived in the same trailer park, and I have come face to face with skunks and a hissing opossum because of it.
>So she decides to sent me out to get the bowl for the little critter so she can feed him.
>I go ahead and do so and who do I meet face to face but sir/madame baby raccoon themselves.
>This little guy/girl was not afraid of me but was cautious (they was backing up a bit).
>I was trying to keep calm, cause I did not want to get attacked by a baby raccoon today.
>So we stare at each other for a bit.
>Suddenly it makes a noise.

>So I got up.
>Went back inside the house.

This thread is dedicated to all animals of the reptilia and amphibia classes. Topics include, but are not limited to: geckos, snakes of all kinds, frogs, salamanders, newts, turtles, tortoises, and much more. Before asking a question, do a search on the internet to see if it has been answered
Classifieds for finding breeders and products:
>morphmarket.com
>kingsnake.com
>faunaclassifieds.com
>reptilescanada.com (Canadian breeders)
>caudata.org
Most forums will have a "for sale" section on them, so look for that, especially if you have a specific herp you want. Craigslist can also be a good source for cheap aquariums, and make sure to check for any reptile expos that occur in your area.

When asking a question, make sure to include these details:
>Type and size of animal
>Enclosure dimensions
>Humidity and temperature
>Type of substrate
>The decor you use
>How often you feed
>The type of food you use
>If your animal is wild caught or captive bred
>How often you handle
>Who you bought the animal from
